reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Battle of Midway
reviews.reviewText: Seeing the battle as a historical fictional with the latest data made for a great read. Great mix of different characters and historical detail.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2023
reviews.reviewText: That time in American history should never be forgotten or glossed over. Had these brave men and, in some cases, boys not answered the call this world would be in worse shape than it already is. The US Pacific fleet rose from the ashes of Dec, 7 1941 and crushed the Imperial Japanese armed forces at a terribly high cost. The USS Enterprise keeps rising and building on the legacy of the Enterprise name. Even now a new Enterprise is under construction ai NNSDC, VA. Enterprise ushered in the time of Nuclear powered Aircraft Carriers and was the only one of her class. The WWII Big ‘E’ was a formidable ship with a crew to match, both brown shoe and black shoe.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Another Good Read by Scott Cook
reviews.reviewText: A historical story about Doolittle's Raid and the Battle of Midway. This book was well written. The story line was real, but the author took some liberties to make it a work of fiction. The only complaint I have about this book is editing. The pilot of a B25 does not fly with egg on his hands. He flies using a YOKE not a yolk. Similarly, you put a bomb down a CHUTE not a shoot.Of course, I'm an Old Fart from the Old School and I've been reading books about WWII since I could read.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Scott Fool's writing made me feel that I was right onboard the ship and part of each of the crews.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great dialogue, but needs an editor and a historian
reviews.reviewText: All of Mr.Cook’s book have great pacing and dialogue, but his ignorance of basic points of US naval history is regrettable. Roger Mehle was a naval hero; his name was not Mealy. Flight controls are on yokes, not yolks. Nobody in the 1940’s said EMCON - they barely knew what radar was. And nobody - nobody - who knew Bill Halsey called him Bull - a nickname from the press that Halsey despised - except Douglas MacArthur. These avoidable errors keep me from giving five stars, because Mr. Cook’s book are enjoyable, readable, and written with great admiration for the Big E and the men who sailed on her. It’s just a shame that with a little care, these errors could be avoided.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Exec novel of the carrier War during the Battle of Midway.
reviews.reviewText: Relive the early days of WW II as you go into action against the IJN flying old and obsolete Devesator bombers against the Zero. The Dauntless dive bombers and Wildcats won the war.

reviews.reviewerName: Pvt. W. G. Kirby Amazon Customer
reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Another installment of an historical fiction of the U.S.S. ENTERPRISE (CV-6) in World War Two
reviews.reviewText: Mr. Cook continues his telling of the story of the USN aircraft carrier ENTERPRISE. The ship is an icon for the courage and tenacity of the ships and members of the US Navy during WWII. It reads very easily and does tell the reader the story of the ship and places it in the correct chronology for the events it participated in. The story of this ship was recorded in the absolutely excellent "The Big E" written by Edward Stafford in the late 1950s, Stafford having been a crew member. It was a bestseller then and continues to sell very well today, 50+ years later. If you want to read THE history this ship in one volume, then find Stafford's book and do so, but you may have to truly look very diligently for the book, as it sells that well. Scott Cook humanizes the story by adding more characters to the events. Many of the actual people are among his groupings, with fictional characters to humanize the story and make it perhaps easier on the casual historian and present generation readers. He slightly manipulates the history a bit, speeding up times and adding dialog that is fictional but tries to stick to the telling of this historical fiction as accurately as he can yet still present his ideas as author. He does NOT alter history or events overall, however there are some anachronisms that creep into each of the volumes I have read that show the author has knowledge of modern naval aviation, but he allows the modernity to make some gaffes that really bother me and other readers I have chatted with who know a bit more about the wartime naval and aviation techniques and situations. Sure his methods do get the story published so as to interest a modern reader who grew up gazing at a monitor and is not a book reader, and show them the history they perhaps missed in their schooling, but the anachronisms do give a false sense of what was really taking place in flying an aircraft to war in the 1940s and operations on a US Navy ship. In a sense, that's "flawed-history" that the reader is being exposed to. Being a retired history educator and military/aviation history "junkie" those errors really bother me. Simple examples: Cook has WWII Navy pilots talking about having to "punch-out" of fatally damaged aircraft. Nope. The term was coined for the use of ejection seats. WWII era US Navy a/c did not have ejection seat technology. Or: Pilots in 1942, taking off advance throttles to get a blasting flame out of the tails of their a/c. Nope. The Navy did not have jet engines on carrier a/c until 1945 (testing) and 1946-47 for beginning of jet operations. Stuff like that and way too many more to please me. The publishers/editors ought to also invest in a proof reader or two before the book goes to press. Such editing ought to be easier than it used to be with computer generated printing procedures. Perhaps a proof reader for historical context would help also ! Oh, and images on the covers are of a/c composites that look....odd, for lack of a better word ! That could be improved upon also. This comes out as a hard and negative review. Nope. I like the book series and the overall success of the stories related and look forward to the rest of the ENTERPRISE stories. The fiction part is good where intended. But the fictional part of the historical events is too often unintentionally too fictional due to errors that could have been avoided. I hope to see future volumes incorporating some improvements.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2023
reviews.reviewText: The word ULTRA would never been shared with the crew. This intel was way too sensitive to risk. Although an American congress man did let it slip with the press.
